channel.title: math.CA updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.CA updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: All convex bodies are in the subdifferential of some everywhere differentiable locally Lipschitz function
item.description: arXiv:2405.09206v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We construct a differentiable locally Lipschitz function $f$ in $\mathbb{R}^{N}$ with the property that for every convex body $K\subset \mathbb{R}^N$ there exists $\bar x \in \mathbb{R}^N$ such that $K$ coincides with the set $\partial_L f(\bar x)$ of limits of derivatives $\{Df(x_n)\}_{n\geq 1}$ of sequences $\{x_n\}_{n\geq 1}$ converging to~$\bar x$. The technique can be further refined to recover all compact connected subsets with nonempty interior, disclosing an important difference between differentiable and continuously differentiable functions. It stems out from our approach that the class of these pathological functions contains an infinite dimensional vector space and is dense in the space of all locally Lipschitz functions for the uniform convergence.
item.dc:creator: Aris Daniilidis (TU Wien), Robert Deville (IMB), Sebastian Tapia-Garcia (TU Wien)

item.title: Optimal constants of smoothing estimates for the 3D Dirac equation
item.description: arXiv:2405.09349v1 Announce Type: cross Abstract: Recently, Ikoma (2022) considered optimal constants and extremisers for the $2$-dimensional Dirac equation using the spherical harmonics decomposition. Though its argument is valid in any dimensions $d \geq 2$, the case $d \geq 3$ remains open since it leads us to too complicated calculation: determining all eigenvalues and eigenvectors of infinite dimensional matrices. In this paper, we give optimal constants and extremisers of smoothing estimates for the $3$-dimensional Dirac equation. In order to prove this, we construct a certain orthonormal basis of spherical harmonics. With respect to this basis, infinite dimensional matrices actually become block diagonal and so that eigenvalues and eigenvectors can be easily found.
item.dc:creator: Makoto Ikoma, Soichiro Suzuki

item.title: Approximation by the Bessel-Riesz Quotient
item.description: arXiv:2306.05610v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: How large is the Bessel potential, $G_{\alpha,\mu}f$, compared to the Riesz potential, $I_\alpha f$, of a given function? We prove that, for certain $f$ and $p$, \[\Vert G_{1,\mu} f\Vert_p\approx \omega(I_1f,1/\mu)_p,\] where $\omega(f,t)_p$ is the $L^p$ modulus of continuity. However, for $0<\alpha<1$, \[\Vert G_{\alpha,\mu}f\Vert_p\leq C(\omega(I_\alpha f,1/\mu)_p)^\alpha\cdot\Vert I_\alpha f\Vert^{1-\alpha}_p.\] These estimates are obtained by studying the quotient of the two operators, $E_{\alpha,\mu}:=\frac{(-\Delta)^{\alpha/2}}{(\mu^2-\Delta)^{\alpha/2}}$, and exploiting its approximation theoretic properties. Additionally, $G_{\alpha,\mu}f=\mathcal{O}(\mu^{-\frac\alpha2})$ if $I_\alpha f$ vanishes near a given point. This ``localization" result is derived from kernel estimates of $E_{\alpha,\mu}$.
item.dc:creator: Ikemefuna Agbanusi

item.title: Algebraicity of hypergeometric functions with arbitrary parameters
item.description: arXiv:2308.12855v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: We provide a complete classification of the algebraicity of (generalized) hypergeometric functions with no restriction on the set of their parameters. Our characterization relies on the interlacing criteria of Christol (1987) and Beukers-Heckman (1989) for globally bounded and algebraic hypergeometric functions, however in a more general setting which allows arbitrary complex parameters with possibly integral differences. We also showcase the adapted criterion on a variety of different examples.
item.dc:creator: Florian F\"urnsinn, Sergey Yurkevich

item.title: Error bounds for a uniform asymptotic approximation of the zeros of the Bessel function $J_{\nu}(x)$
item.dc:creator: T. M. Dunster

item.title: Optimal constants of smoothing estimates for Dirac equations with radial data
item.description: arXiv:2306.08982v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Kato--Yajima smoothing estimates are one of the fundamental results in study of dispersive equations such as Schr\"odinger equations and Dirac equations. For $d$-dimensional Schr\"odinger-type equations ($d \geq 2$), optimal constants of smoothing estimates were obtained by Bez--Saito--Sugimoto (2017) via the so-called Funk--Hecke theorem. Recently Ikoma (2022) considered optimal constants for $d$-dimensional Dirac equations using a similar method, and it was revealed that determining optimal constants for Dirac equations is much harder than the case of Schr\"odinger-type equations. Indeed, Ikoma obtained the optimal constant in the case $d = 2$, but only upper bounds (which seem not optimal) were given in other dimensions. In this paper, we give optimal constants for $d$-dimensional Schr\"odinger-type and Dirac equations with radial initial data for any $d \geq 2$. In addition, we also give optimal constants for the one-dimensional Schr\"odinger-type and Dirac equations.
item.dc:creator: Makoto Ikoma, Soichiro Suzuki
